entry.title: Flood Watch issued September 18 at 3:28AM EDT by NWS
entry.summary: .Low pressure moving northward off the Mid Atlantic Coast will move into the Gulf of Maine tonight. This low will be accompanied by tropical moisture and the result will be rain, heavy at times starting today and lasting through tonight. Flooding will be possible including a few instances of flash flooding. ...FLOOD WATCH IN EFFECT FROM THIS AFTERNOON THROUGH TUESDAY

entry.summary: ...WINDY AND DRY CONDITIONS THROUGH MONDAY... .A pair of dry cold fronts will sweep through the region today and Monday, making for breezy conditions during the afternoon and evening hours each day. entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued September 18 at 1:33AM CDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...FOG AND PATCHY FROST EARLY THIS MORNING... Areas of fog, some dense, and patchy fog will develop tonight across portions of northwest Wisconsin. The visibility in fog may drop to a half mile or less creating hazardous driving conditions in spots. The frost will be more likely inland from Lake Superior. If the dense fog becomes widespread, a Dense Fog Advisory may be
entry.cap:areaDesc: Ashland; Bayfield; Iron; Price; Sawyer

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued September 17 at 2:28PM CDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...DENSE FOG AND PATCHY FROST EXPECTED TONIGHT... Areas of ground fog may become locally dense fog across central, north- central, and far northeast Wisconsin late tonight. Rapid reductions of visibilities below one quarter mile are possible in the fog, which could make the Monday morning commute hazardous at times. Where fog develops, visibilities are expected
